title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: The big fashion show is being planned for next week.  The show includes runway models strutting up and down the runway wearing designer clothing in front of an audience.  There are two parts to the show: evening wear and bathing suits.  It takes a model 2 minutes to walk out to the end of the runway and back, and models take turns, one at a time, walking the runway up and back, while wearing different clothes.  If there are 6 models in the show, and each model will wear two sets of bathing suits and three sets of evening wear clothing during the runway portion of the show, how long will it take, in minutes, to complete all of the runway trips during the show?

Each model will wear 2 sets of bathing suits + 3 sets of evening wear = <<2+3=5>>5 sets of clothing.
For each set of clothing, it takes 2 minutes to go out and back on the runway.
For 5 sets of clothing, it takes 5 sets * 2 minutes/set = <<5*2=10>>10 minutes.
With 6 different models, it will take 6 models * 10 minutes/model = <<6*10=60>>60 minutes. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: The big fashion show is being planned for next week.  The show includes runway models strutting up and down the runway wearing designer clothing in front of an audience.  There are two parts to the show: evening wear and bathing suits.  It takes a model 2 minutes to walk out to the end of the runway and back, and models take turns, one at a time, walking the runway up and back, while wearing different clothes.  If there are 6 models in the show, and each model will wear two sets of bathing suits and three sets of evening wear clothing during the runway portion of the show, how long will it take, in minutes, to complete all of the runway trips during the show?

Each model will take a total of 2 minutes x 2 sets of bathing suits + 2 minutes x 3 sets of evening wear = <<2*2+2*3=10>>10 minutes per trip down the runway.
With 6 models in the show, it will take 10 minutes per trip x 6 models = <<10*6=60>>60 minutes to complete all the runway trips during the show. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: The big fashion show is being planned for next week.  The show includes runway models strutting up and down the runway wearing designer clothing in front of an audience.  There are two parts to the show: evening wear and bathing suits.  It takes a model 2 minutes to walk out to the end of the runway and back, and models take turns, one at a time, walking the runway up and back, while wearing different clothes.  If there are 6 models in the show, and each model will wear two sets of bathing suits and three sets of evening wear clothing during the runway portion of the show, how long will it take, in minutes, to complete all of the runway trips during the show?

Each model will make 5 trips down the runway: 2 trips wearing bathing suits + 3 trips wearing evening wear = <<2+3=5>>5 trips.
If there are 6 models in the show, there will be a total of 6 x 5 = <<6*5=30>>30 trips down the runway.
Since each trip takes 2 minutes, it will take 30 x 2 = <<30*2=60>>60 minutes to complete all of the runway trips during the show. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Julio receives a $1 commission for every customer that buys in Edgars Fashion Store. The store sells to 35 customers in the first week, twice as many in the second week, and triple as many as the first week in the third week. If he receives a salary of $500 for the 3 weeks and a bonus of $50, how much in total does he earn for the 3 weeks?

Julio sells to 35 customers in the first week, and since he receives $1 for every sale, he earns 35*$1 = $<<35*1=35>>35 in the first week.
The fashion store sells to twice as many customers as in the first week in the second week, which is 2*35 = <<2*35=70>>70 customers.
He earns 70*$1 = $<<70*1=70>>70 from the sales in the second week.
In the third week, he sells to triple the first week customers, which is 35*3 = <<35*3=105>>105 customers.
He earns $1 for every sale, meaning he earns 105*$1 = $<<105*1=105>>105 in the third week.
The total earning from the sales is $105+$70+$35 = $<<105+70+35=210>>210
Julio earns $500 salary + $50 bonus = $<<500+50=550>>550 from salary and bonus
His total earning for the 3 weeks is $550+$210 = $<<550+210=760>>760. Answer: \boxed{760}.


Question: Julio receives a $1 commission for every customer that buys in Edgars Fashion Store. The store sells to 35 customers in the first week, twice as many in the second week, and triple as many as the first week in the third week. If he receives a salary of $500 for the 3 weeks and a bonus of $50, how much in total does he earn for the 3 weeks?

If Edgars Fashion Store sells to 35 customers in the first week, and he receives $1 commission for every customer that buys in the store, he earns $1 x 35 = $<<1*35=35>>35 for the first week.
The store sells twice as many customers in the second week, which is 35 x 2 = <<35*2=70>>70 customers
His earnings for the second week for commission are $1 x 70 = $<<1*70=70>>70
The store sells triple the number of customers in the first week, which is 35 x 3 = <<35*3=105>>105 customers
His earnings in the third week for commission is $1 x 105 = $<<1*105=105>>105
His total earnings in commission for the three weeks are, $35 + $70 + $105 = $<<35+70+105=210>>210
He receives a salary of $500 for the three weeks and a bonus of $50, so his total earnings for the three weeks are $500 + $50 + $210 = $<<500+50+210=760>>760. Answer: \boxed{760}.


Question: The big fashion show is being planned for next week.  The show includes runway models strutting up and down the runway wearing designer clothing in front of an audience.  There are two parts to the show: evening wear and bathing suits.  It takes a model 2 minutes to walk out to the end of the runway and back, and models take turns, one at a time, walking the runway up and back, while wearing different clothes.  If there are 6 models in the show, and each model will wear two sets of bathing suits and three sets of evening wear clothing during the runway portion of the show, how long will it take, in minutes, to complete all of the runway trips during the show?
text:
There are 6 models in the show, and each model will make 5 trips down the runway (2 trips wearing bathing suits + 3 trips wearing evening wear). So, there will be a total of 6 models * 5 trips/model = 30 trips down the runway.
Since each trip takes 2 minutes, it will take a total of 30 trips * 2 minutes/trip = 60 minutes to complete all of the runway trips during the show. Answer: \boxed{60}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A reporter is paid by the word and per article. She earns $.1 per word. She earns $60 per article. She has to finish three stories in the next 4 hours. She averages 10 words a minute. How much can she expect to earn per hour if she writes the entire time?

The reporter can write for a total of 4 hours x 60 minutes = <<4*60=240>>240 minutes.
Therefore, she can write a total of 240 minutes x 10 words/minute = <<240*10=2400>>2400 words.
She will therefore earn a total of 2400 words x $.1/word = $<<2400*0.1=240>>240.
As she can earn $60 three times, she will therefore earn $60 x 3 = $<<60*3=180>>180 from her articles.
Thus, her total earnings will be $240 + $180 = $<<240+180=420>>420.
Therefore, she can expect to earn $420 / 4 hours = $<<420/4=105>>105 per hour. Answer: \boxed{105}.


Question: Janet is getting paid to moderate social media posts. She gets paid 25 cents per post she checks. If it takes her 10 seconds to check a post, how much does she earn per hour?

There are 60 seconds in a minute and 60 minutes in an hour, so there are 60*60=<<60*60=3600>>3600 seconds in an hour.
She can check 3600/10=<<3600/10=360>>360 posts per hour.
She earns 360*$0.25=$<<360*0.25=90>>90 per hour. Answer: \boxed{90}.


Question: Maggie has an after-school job that pays her $5.00 for every magazine subscription she can sell.  She sells 4 to her parents, 1 to her grandfather, 2 to the next-door neighbor and twice that amount to another neighbor.  How much money did Maggie earn?

She earns $5/sale and sells 4 subscriptions, so her parents cover 4*$5=$<<5*4=20.00>>20.00 in magazine subscriptions.
She earns $5/magazine sold and sells 1 magazine to her grandfather, so he covers 1*$5=$<<5*1=5.00>>5.00 in magazine subscriptions.
She earns $5/magazine sold and sells a total of 2 magazines to the next door neighbor, so this neighbor covers 2*$5=$<<5*2=10.00>>10.00 in magazine subscriptions.
She gets 2*$5=$<<2*5=10.00>>10.00/sale from one neighbor and sells twice that amount, so these 2 neighbors pay her additional 2*$10.00=$<<2*10=20.00>>20.00.
In total, she earns $20.00 from her parents, $5.00 from her grandfather, $10.00 from her next door neighbor, and $20.00 from her additional subscriptions making a grand total of $20+$5+$10+$20=$<<20+5+10+20=55.00>>55.00. Answer: \boxed{55}.


Question: Janet is getting paid to moderate social media posts. She gets paid 25 cents per post she checks. If it takes her 10 seconds to check a post, how much does she earn per hour?

There are 60 minutes in an hour, so there are 60 / 10 = <<60/10=6>>6 sets of 10 seconds in a minute.
So, Janet earns $0.25 x 6 = $<<0.25*6=1.50>>1.50 in a minute.
Therefore, she earns $1.50 x 60 = $<<1.5*60=90>>90 per hour. Answer: \boxed{90}.


Question: Janet is trying to decide whether to quit her job and start freelancing. She works 40 hours a week at both jobs. She get paid $30/hour at her current job, and would get paid $40/hour as a freelancer. However, she'd have to pay an extra $25 a week in FICA taxes plus $400/month in healthcare premiums. How much more would Janet make per month as a freelancer if there are four weeks in a month?

Janet currently makes 40 hours/week * $30/hour = $<<40*30=1200>>1200 per week.
Thus, she currently makes $1200/week * 4 weeks/month = $<<1200*4=4800>>4800 per month.
As a freelancer, she would make 40 hours/week * $40/hour = $<<40*40=1600>>1600 per week.
Thus, she would make $1600/week * 4 weeks/month = $<<1600*4=6400>>6400 per month.
Janet would pay an extra $25/week * 4 weeks/month = $<<25*4=100>>100 per month in FICA taxes.
She would also pay an extra $400/month in healthcare premiums.
Thus, she would make $6400 - $4800 - $100 - $400 = $<<6400-4800-100-400=1100>>1100 more per month as a freelancer. Answer: \boxed{1100}.


Question: A reporter is paid by the word and per article. She earns $.1 per word. She earns $60 per article. She has to finish three stories in the next 4 hours. She averages 10 words a minute. How much can she expect to earn per hour if she writes the entire time?
text:
The reporter can write for a total of 4 hours x 60 minutes = 240 minutes.
Therefore, she can write a total of 240 minutes x 10 words/minute = 2400 words.
She will therefore earn a total of 2400 words x $.1/word = $240.
As she can earn $60 three times, she will therefore earn $60 x 3 = $180 from her articles.
Thus, her total earnings will be $240 + $180 = $420.
Therefore, she can expect to earn $420 / 4 hours = $105 per hour. Answer: \boxed{105}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Julie, Letitia and Anton decided to have dinner together at a nearby restaurant.  Julie orders $10 worth of food, Letitia orders $20 worth of food, and Anton orders $30 worth of food.  How much should each pay in tips if they want to split a 20% tip for the whole meal evenly?

The total cost of the food is $10 + $20 + $30 = $<<10+20+30=60>>60.
The total tip amount is $60 * 0.20 = $<<60*0.20=12>>12.
Each person should pay $12 / 3 = $<<12/3=4>>4 in tips. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Julie, Letitia and Anton decided to have dinner together at a nearby restaurant.  Julie orders $10 worth of food, Letitia orders $20 worth of food, and Anton orders $30 worth of food.  How much should each pay in tips if they want to split a 20% tip for the whole meal evenly?

The total cost of the meal is $10 + $20 + $30 = $<<10+20+30=60>>60.
They want to split a 20% tip for the meal, so the total tip amount is $60 x 0.20 = $<<60*0.20=12>>12.
There are three people splitting the tip, so each person should pay $12 / 3 = $<<12/3=4>>4 in tips. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Julie, Letitia and Anton decided to have dinner together at a nearby restaurant.  Julie orders $10 worth of food, Letitia orders $20 worth of food, and Anton orders $30 worth of food.  How much should each pay in tips if they want to split a 20% tip for the whole meal evenly?

The total cost of the food is $10 + $20 + $30 = $<<10+20+30=60>>60
A 20% tip on a $60 meal is (20/100)*60 = $12
They want to split this evenly so each person should pay $12 / 3 people = $<<12/3=4>>4. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Julie, Letitia and Anton decided to have dinner together at a nearby restaurant.  Julie orders $10 worth of food, Letitia orders $20 worth of food, and Anton orders $30 worth of food.  How much should each pay in tips if they want to split a 20% tip for the whole meal evenly?

The total bill comes to $10 + $20 + $30 = $<<10+20+30=60>>60.
The total tip they want to leave is $60 * 0.20 = $<<60*0.20=12>>12.
Each person should pay $12 / 3 = $<<12/3=4>>4 in tips. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Leticia, Scarlett, and Percy decide to eat at a Greek restaurant for lunch. The prices for their dishes cost $10, $13, and $17, respectively. If the trio gives the waiter a 10% tip, how much gratuity should the waiter receive in dollars?

The sum of their dishes' prices is $10 + $13 + $17 = $<<10+13+17=40>>40.
The tip that the trio will give is 10/100 * $40 = $<<10/100*40=4>>4. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Julie, Letitia and Anton decided to have dinner together at a nearby restaurant.  Julie orders $10 worth of food, Letitia orders $20 worth of food, and Anton orders $30 worth of food.  How much should each pay in tips if they want to split a 20% tip for the whole meal evenly?
text:
The total cost of the meal is $10 + $20 + $30 = $<<10+20+30=60>>60.
They want to split a 20% tip for the meal evenly, so the total tip amount is $60 x 0.20 = $<<60*0.20=12>>12.
Since there are three people splitting the tip, each person should pay $12 / 3 = $<<12/3=4>>4 in tips. Answer: \boxed{4}.

Question: Cassandra collected 5000 pennies for the charity drive. James collected 276 fewer pennies. How many pennies did they donate to charity?

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Johnny buys 15 packs of colored pencils for his class. Each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside. When he gets home he notices that 3 of the packs have two extra red pencils inside. How many red colored pencils did Johnny buy?

Johnny bought 3 packs x 2 extra red pencils = <<3*2=6>>6 extra red colored pencils.
He bought 15 packs x 1 red pencil in each = <<15*1=15>>15 red colored pencils.
Thus, he bought 15 + 6 = <<15+6=21>>21 red colored pencils. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: Johnny buys 15 packs of colored pencils for his class. Each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside. When he gets home he notices that 3 of the packs have two extra red pencils inside. How many red colored pencils did Johnny buy?

Johnny bought 15 packs of colored pencils, and each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside, so there are 15 * 1 = <<15*1=15>>15 red colored pencils.
Three of the packs have two extra red pencils inside, so there are 3 * 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 extra red colored pencils.
Johnny bought 15 + 6 = <<15+6=21>>21 red colored pencils. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: Johnny buys 15 packs of colored pencils for his class. Each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside. When he gets home he notices that 3 of the packs have two extra red pencils inside. How many red colored pencils did Johnny buy?

Johnny bought 15 packs * 1 red pencil = <<15*1=15>>15 red pencils.
Also, 3 packs * 2 extra red pencils = <<3*2=6>>6 extra red pencils were inside these packs.
So in total Johnny bought 15 red pencils + 6 extra red pencils = <<15+6=21>>21 red colored pencils. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: Johnny buys 15 packs of colored pencils for his class. Each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside. When he gets home he notices that 3 of the packs have two extra red pencils inside. How many red colored pencils did Johnny buy?

Johnny bought 15 packs so he bought 15 red packs * 1 red pencil per pack = <<15*1=15>>15 red colored pencils.
3 packs were overfilled, 3 packs * 2 extra red pencils = <<3*2=6>>6 extra red colored pencils.
Johnny bought 15 red pencils + 6 extra red pencils = <<15+6=21>>21 red colored pencils. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: Johnny is a guitar player and he has three colors of guitar picks: red, blue, and yellow. Half of his picks are red, one-third of the picks are blue, and the rest are yellow.  If he has 12 blue picks, what is the total number of yellow picks in his collection?

The number of blue picks is 1/3rd of the total number of picks, so 1/3 of his total number of picks is 12 picks, 12*3= <<1/3*3=1>>36 picks
If half of Johnny's picks are red, he has 1/2*36= <<1/2*36=18>>18 red picks
The number of yellow picks is 36 picks - 18 picks - 12 picks= <<36-18-12=6>>6 yellow picks. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Johnny buys 15 packs of colored pencils for his class. Each pack has a red, yellow, and green pencil inside. When he gets home he notices that 3 of the packs have two extra red pencils inside. How many red colored pencils did Johnny buy?
text: Johnny bought 15 packs of colored pencils. Since each pack has one red pencil, he bought 15 red pencils. Additionally, 3 packs had two extra red pencils, so there were 3 x 2 = 6 extra red pencils. Therefore, Johnny bought a total of 15 + 6 = 21 red colored pencils. Answer: \boxed{21}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?

Randy received a total of 13 + 15 = <<13+15=28>>28 biscuits as gifts.
The total number of biscuits Randy had is 32 + 28 = <<32+28=60>>60 biscuits.
After his brother ate some, Randy is left with 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?

Randy has a total of 32 + 13 + 15 = <<32+13+15=60>>60 biscuits.
After his brother ate 20 biscuits, Randy is left with 60 – 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?

Randy had 32 biscuits.
His father gave him 13 biscuits.
Randy then had 32 + 13 = <<32+13=45>>45 biscuits.
His mother gave him 15 biscuits.
Randy then had 45 + 15 = <<45+15=60>>60 biscuits.
His brother ate 20 of these biscuits.
Randy was then left with 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?

Randy's father and mother gave him a total of 13 + 15 = <<13+15=28>>28 biscuits.
He was left with 32 + 28 = <<32+28=60>>60 biscuits.
After his brother ate 20, Randy is left with 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?

Randy's father gave him 13 biscuits.
His mother gave him 15 biscuits.
So, Randy had 32 + 13 + 15 = <<32+13+15=60>>60 biscuits.
But his brother ate 20 biscuits.
Therefore, Randy is left with 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.


Question: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift. His mother gave him 15 biscuits. Randy’s brother ate 20 of these biscuits. How many biscuits are Randy left with?
text: Randy had 32 biscuits. His father gave him 13 biscuits as a gift, so Randy then had 32 + 13 = <<32+13=45>>45 biscuits. His mother gave him 15 biscuits, so Randy then had 45 + 15 = <<45+15=60>>60 biscuits. Finally, Randy's brother ate 20 of these biscuits, leaving Randy with 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 biscuits. Answer: \boxed{40}.

Question: Travis goes through 2 boxes of cereal a week.  If each box costs $3.00 and he eats 2 boxes every week for an entire year, 52 weeks, how much does he spend on cereal?

Each box cost $3.00 so he spends 104*$3=$<<104*3=312.00>>312.00 on cereal. Answer: \boxed{312}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Five people are planning a party. Sonja will buy a loaf of French bread ($3 a loaf) and a platter of cold cuts ($23). Barbara will buy the soda ($1 per person) and two boxes of crackers ($2 per box). Mario and Rick will split the cost of two packages of Cheese Doodles ($3 per package). Danica will supply a package of paper plates for $4. How much more will Sonja spend than the rest of the office put together?

Sonja will spend $3 + $23 = $<<3+23=26>>26.
Barbara will spend 5 x $1 = $<<5*1=5>>5 on soda.
Barbara will spend 2 x $2 = $<<2*2=4>>4 on crackers.
Barbara will spend a total of $5 + $4 = $<<5+4=9>>9.
Mario and Rick will spend 2 x $3 = $<<2*3=6>>6 on Cheese Doodles.
Danica will spend $4 on paper plates.
The rest of the office will spend $9 + $6 + $4 = $<<9+6+4=19>>19.
Sonja will spend $26 - $19 = $<<26-19=7>>7 more than the rest of the office. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: Five people are planning a party. Sonja will buy a loaf of French bread ($3 a loaf) and a platter of cold cuts ($23). Barbara will buy the soda ($1 per person) and two boxes of crackers ($2 per box). Mario and Rick will split the cost of two packages of Cheese Doodles ($3 per package). Danica will supply a package of paper plates for $4. How much more will Sonja spend than the rest of the office put together?

Sonja will spend $3 + $23 = $<<3+23=26>>26.
Barbara will spend 1 * 5 = $<<1*5=5>>5 on soda.
Barbara will spend 2 * 2 = $<<2*2=4>>4 on crackers.
Barbara will spend a total of $5 + $4 = $<<5+4=9>>9.
Mario and Rick will spend a total of 3 * 2 = $<<3*2=6>>6 on Cheese Doodles.
In total, Barbara, Mario, Rick, and Danica will spend $9 + $6 + $4 = $<<9+6+4=19>>19.
Sonja will spend $26 - $19 = $<<26-19=7>>7 more than the rest of the office. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: Five people are planning a party. Sonja will buy a loaf of French bread ($3 a loaf) and a platter of cold cuts ($23). Barbara will buy the soda ($1 per person) and two boxes of crackers ($2 per box). Mario and Rick will split the cost of two packages of Cheese Doodles ($3 per package). Danica will supply a package of paper plates for $4. How much more will Sonja spend than the rest of the office put together?

Sonja will spend 3 + 23 = $<<3+23=26>>26.
Barbara will spend 1 * 5 + 2 * 2 = $<<1*5+2*2=9>>9.
Mario and Rick will spend 2 * 3 = $<<2*3=6>>6.
Danica will spend 4.
The rest of the people will spend 9 + 6 + 4 = $<<9+6+4=19>>19.
Sonja will spend 26 - 19 = $<<26-19=7>>7 more. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: Four people in a law firm are planning a party. Mary will buy a platter of pasta for $20 and a loaf of bread for $2. Elle and Andrea will split the cost for buying 4 cans of soda which cost $1.50 each, and chicken wings for $10. Joe will buy a cake that costs $5. How much more will Mary spend than the rest of the firm put together?

Mary will spend a total of $20 + $2 = $<<20+2=22>>22.
Elle and Andrea will spend a total of $1.50 x 4 = $<<1.5*4=6>>6 for soda.
They will also spend a total of $6 + $10 = $<<6+10=16>>16 for soda and chicken wings.
Joe will spend a total of $5.
The total amount that Elle, Andrea, and Joe will spend is $16 + $5 = $<<16+5=21>>21.
Therefore, Mary will spend $22 - $21 = $<<22-21=1>>1 more than the rest of the firm put together. Answer: \boxed{1}.


Question: Monica and Michelle are combining their money to throw a party. Monica brings $15. Michelle brings $12. The cake costs 15 dollars, and soda is $3 a bottle. Each bottle of soda has 12 servings and they buy as many bottles of soda as they can afford. If there are 8 total guests, how many servings of soda does each get?

They have 15+12=<<15+12=27>>27 dollars total
They buy 27-15=<<27-15=12>>12 dollars worth of soda
They can buy 12/3=<<12/3=4>>4 bottles of soda
They have 4*12=<<4*12=48>>48 servings of soda
If there are 8 guests, each gets 48/8=<<48/8=6>>6 servings of soda each. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Five people are planning a party. Sonja will buy a loaf of French bread ($3 a loaf) and a platter of cold cuts ($23). Barbara will buy the soda ($1 per person) and two boxes of crackers ($2 per box). Mario and Rick will split the cost of two packages of Cheese Doodles ($3 per package). Danica will supply a package of paper plates for $4. How much more will Sonja spend than the rest of the office put together?
text:
Sonja will spend $3 + $23 = $26.
Barbara will spend 5 x $1 = $5 on soda.
Barbara will spend 2 x $2 = $4 on crackers.
Barbara will spend a total of $5 + $4 = $9.
Mario and Rick will spend 2 x $3 = $6 on Cheese Doodles.
Danica will spend $4 on paper plates.
The rest of the office will spend $9 + $6 + $4 = $19.
Sonja will spend $26 - $19 = $7 more than the rest of the office. Answer: \boxed{7}.
